concepts.unlisted_description: Culpable homicide not amounting to murder

issues.text: Whether the complicity of Harchand Singh and Jaswant Singh was established beyond any reasonable doubt for conviction under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: the High Court after taking into consideration the evidence of those three witnesses as well the evidence of Ram Asra PW came to the conclusion that the complicity of Harchand Singh and Jaswant Singh was established beyond any reasonable doubt. So far as Jaswinder Singh was concerned, the High Court held that no case has been proved against them. The High Court was further of the opinion that the case against Harchand Singh and Jaswant Singh fell under section 302 read with section 34 and not under section 304 part II read with section 34 Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: Whether the testimony of Amarjit Singh, Mal Singh and Teja Singh as eyewitnesses is reliable and can form the basis of conviction

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of one set consists of the testimony of Amarjit Singh, Mal Singh and Teja Singh. So far as these witnesses are concerned, the trial court came to the conclusion that they were not present near the scene of occurrence and had not witnessed the occurrence. The trial court in support of this conclusion gave reasons which appear to be cogent and weighty and find no particular ground to take a different view.

issues.text: Whether the testimony of Ram Asra PW 14 is reliable, particularly given its omission from the dying declaration and contradiction by other prosecution evidence

anchor.surface_text: So far as this witness is concerned, we find that his presence at the scene of occurrence was not mentioned by Ajaib Singh deceased in the dying declaration which was recorded by ASI Harbhajan Singh at Khanna hospital. According to Ram Asra, he was working with the deceased at the well when the three accused came there and assaulted the deceased.

issues.text: Whether the case falls under section 302 read with section 34 or section 304 part II read with section 34 Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was further of the opinion that the case against Harchand Singh and Jaswant Singh fell under section 302 read with section 34 and not under section 304 part II read with section 34 Indian Penal Code. Harchand Singh and Jaswant Singh were accordingly convicted

issues.text: Whether conviction for murder can be based on the testimony of a single eyewitness if it is convincing and reliable, and whether Ram Asra's testimony qualifies

holdings.text: The conviction of the appellants cannot be sustained

anchor.surface_text: We have heard Mr. Nuruddin on behalf of the appellants and Mr. Marwah on behalf of the State and are of the opinion that the convinction of the appellants cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution evidence consists of two contradictory sets of eyewitnesses, neither reliable, leaving no trustworthy basis for conviction

holdings.text: Trial court's conclusion that Amarjit Singh, Mal Singh and Teja Singh were not present near the scene and did not witness the occurrence is correct

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of one set consists of the testimony of Amarjit Singh, Mal Singh and Teja Singh. So far as these witnesses are concerned, the trial court came to the conclusion that they were not present near the scene of occurrence and had not witnessed the occurrence.

holdings.text: Ram Asra PW14 is an unreliable witness
holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence omitted from dying declaration; contradicted by Amarjit, Mal, Teja who say he did not witness; prosecution evidence discredits him

holdings.text: When prosecution leads two contradictory sets of evidence, each discrediting the other, accused entitled to benefit of doubt
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court's function requires reliable evidence for conviction; self-contradictory prosecution case leaves no firm ground

holdings.text: Conviction on single eyewitness possible if convincing and reliable, but Ram Asra's testimony does not qualify
holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle from Vadivalu Thevar affirmed, but inapplicable as prosecution evidence itself discredits the witness
